content:
The "Satellite Home Viewer Act of 1994" may be cited as the short title. This Act provides a statutory license for satellite carriers. Section 119 of title 17, United States Code, is amended to clarify requirements for satellite carriers regarding secondary transmissions of network station broadcasts for private home viewing to unserved households. Section 119 of title 17, United States Code, is amended to clarify requirements for satellite carriers regarding secondary transmissions of network station broadcasts for private home viewing to unserved households. The subsections are amended to adjust fees and deadlines for compliance. Section 119 of title 17, United States Code, is amended to clarify requirements for satellite carriers regarding secondary transmissions of network station broadcasts for private home viewing to unserved households. Amendments include adjusting fees and deadlines for compliance, such as changing dates from 1994 to December 31, 1999, and from 1991 to January 1, 1997. The Copyright Arbitration Panel will establish royalty fees based on fair market value for retransmission of network stations and superstations. The amendments to Section 119 of title 17, United States Code, clarify requirements for satellite carriers regarding secondary transmissions of network station broadcasts for private home viewing to unserved households. This includes adjusting fees, deadlines, and establishing royalty fees based on fair market value for retransmission of network stations and superstations. The parties will consider the competitive environment, economic impact of fees, and impact on the availability of secondary transmissions to the public. The amendments to Section 119 of title 17, United States Code, involve adjusting fees and deadlines for satellite carriers regarding secondary transmissions of network station broadcasts. This includes establishing royalty fees based on fair market value for retransmission of network stations and superstations, with considerations for the competitive environment and economic impact. Additionally, the amendments remove the end date of December 31, 1994, and replace it with "or July 1, 1997, whichever is later" after "section 802(g". The amendments to Section 119 of title 17, United States Code involve adjusting fees and deadlines for satellite carriers regarding secondary transmissions of network station broadcasts. This includes establishing royalty fees based on fair market value for retransmission of network stations and superstations, with considerations for the competitive environment and economic impact. Additionally, there are provisions for transitional signal intensity measurement procedures in case of challenges by network stations regarding unserved households within predicted Grade B Contour. If a measurement indicates a household is not unserved, the satellite carrier must terminate service to that household within specific timeframes. The Satellite Home Viewer Act of 1994 limits signal intensity measurements for satellite carriers to 5 percent of subscribers in a network station's local market. If a household is challenged as unserved, the challenging station must reimburse the carrier for measurement costs within 60 days. The Satellite Home Viewer Act of 1994 limits signal intensity measurements for satellite carriers to 5 percent of subscribers in a network station's local market. If a household is challenged as unserved, the carrier must terminate service within 60 days of receiving the measurement indicating the household is not unserved. The network station must reimburse the cost of signal intensity measurement within 60 days. If a subscriber is challenged as unserved outside the predicted Grade B Contour, the station can conduct a signal intensity measurement with notice to the satellite carrier. If the measurement shows the household is not unserved, the carrier must terminate service within 60 days. The network station must reimburse the cost of signal intensity measurement within 60 days. If a subscriber is challenged as unserved, the station can conduct a measurement and if found unserved, the station pays for the measurement costs. The satellite carrier and network station must reimburse each other for signal intensity measurements within 60 days. If a household is challenged as unserved, the responsible party pays for the measurement costs. The satellite carrier must conduct a site measurement of its signal at a subscriber's household. If denied access or unable to conduct the measurement, service to that household must be terminated within 60 days. The term 'network station' refers to a television broadcast station affiliated with a television network in the United States. The term 'local market' is defined as the area within a network station's predicted Grade B contour by the Federal Communications Commission. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

(a) Cable System.--Section 111(f) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include "microwave" in the definition of a cable system.
(b) Local Service Area.--Section 111(f) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include the definition of a local service area of a primary transmitter within a station's television market as defined in the Code of Federal Regulations.

SEC. 4. TERMINATION. SEC. 4. TERMINATION. The amendments made by this section apply only to section 119 of title 17, United States Code, and cease to be effective on December 31, 1999. Section 207 of the Satellite Home Viewer Act of 1988 is repealed. The Act and its amendments take effect upon enactment, with specific provisions regarding burden of proof and signal intensity measurements effective on certain dates. The amendment made in 1996 regarding the local service area of a primary transmitter will be effective on July 1, 1994.
